questions.text: What is the time taken for capacitation of the sperm?
questions.solution:
The time taken for the capacitation of sperms is 6-8 hours (approximately 7 hours).

Sperms have to undergo two changes in the female reproductive tract to be able to fertilise the ovum:

1) Capacitation 

  • It is the functional maturation of the spermatozoa. 
  • It occurs in the fallopian tube and involves epithelial interactions between the sperm and the mucosal surface of the tube.
  • The glycoprotein coat and seminal plasma proteins are removed.
  • Only capacitated sperms can pass through the corona cells and undergo the acrosomal reaction.

2) Acrosomal reaction 

  • It occurs after binding to zona pellucida, induced by zona proteins. 
  • Enzymes such as acrosin and trypsin-like protein are released to penetrate the zona pellucida 
  • Ca2+ plays an important role.

questions.text: The following figure shows the transverse section of the uterus with an implanted zygote. Identify structure A.
questions.solution:
In the given image, the decidua basalis is marked as A. This part of the decidua forms the placenta.

Implantation occurs 6 to 7 days after fertilization. After implantation, the endometrium is called the decidua. It is of the following types:

  • Decidua basalis - present over chorion frondosum. Decidua basalis and chorion frondosum form the placenta. 
  • Decidua capsularis - present over abembryonic pole. 
  • Decidua parietalis - present on the opposite side of the uterus.

The villi cover the entire surface of the chorion during the early weeks. As the fetus grows, the villi on the embryonic pole continue to grow, giving rise to the chorion frondosum. At the abembryonic pole, the villi degenerate. By the third month, this side of the chorion becomes smooth, and is called the chorion laeve.

As the fetus grows, the chorion laeve comes into contact with the decidua parietalis on the opposite side of the uterus, and fusion occurs. Thus, the uterine lumen is obliterated. The amnion and chorion fuse, to form the amniochorionic membrane. Rupture of the amniochorionic membrane during labor is called 'breaking of waters'.

Note: Superfetation can theoretically occur till the time the uterine lumen is not obliterated.

questions.text:
All of the following statements are true regarding oogenesis except:

LH- Luteinizing hormone

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrests in prophase of 1st meiotic division
Secondary oocyte arrests in metaphase of 1st meiotic division
Secondary oocyte arrests in metaphase of 2nd meiotic division
1st meiotic division of the secondary follicle resumes with LH surge

questions.solution:
The second statement i.e. that secondary oocytes arrest in metaphase of the first meiotic division is not true.

The secondary oocyte actually arrests in the metaphase of the second meiotic division. (Option C)

Other options-

Option (A): The primary oocyte arrests in the prophase of the 1st meiotic division (diplotene stage). These primary oocytes remain arrested in this manner until puberty. They become surrounded by a layer of flat epithelial cells and are then called primordial follicles.

Option (D): The 1st meiotic division of the secondary follicle resumes with the cyclical LH (luteinizing hormone) surge. This is the parameter required for ovulation to occur.

questions.text: The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by ______.
questions.solution:
The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by Caldwell and Moloy.

The greatest transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet divides the pelvis into anterior and posterior segments. The shapes of these segments help classify the pelvis as follows:

  • Gynecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

The various differences between these types is summarised below:

  Gynecoid  Anthropoid  Android  Platypelloid 
Shape  Round  Anteroposteriorly oval  Triangular/ Heart-shaped  Transversely oval / Flat bowl shaped
Sacral angle >90°  >90° <90° >90°
Side walls  Straight or slightly divergent  Straight or divergent  Convergent  Divergent 
Ischial spines  Not prominent  Not prominent  Prominent  Not prominent 
Subpubic angle   Wide (85°)  Slightly narrow  Narrow  Very wide (>90°) 
Fetal Position 

Occipitolateral 

Oblique occipitoanterior 

Direct occipitoanterior

Occipitoposterior 

Occipitolateral

Oblique occipitoposterior 

 Occipitolateral 
Engaging diameter Transverse / oblique  Anteroposterior  Transverse / oblique  Transverse 
Delivery  No difficulty   Face-to-pubis - most common.

Deep transverse arrest is common.

Difficult delivery with an increased chance of perineal injuries 

 No difficulty 

Option B: McAfee and Johnson's regimen is for the conservative management of placenta previa.

Option C: Page's and Sher's classification system is used to grade abruptio placentae. 

Option D: Burns and Marshall maneuver is used in breech delivery.

questions.text: An obese woman with dysmenorrhea and irregular periods is diagnosed with dystocia dystrophia syndrome. What type of pelvis is seen here?
questions.solution:
In dystocia dystrophia syndrome, an android pelvis is seen.

Dystocia dystrophia syndrome:

  • The patient is stockily built with a bull neck, broad shoulders, and short thighs. She is obese with a male distribution of hair.
  • Subfertile, with dysmenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, or irregular periods.
  • There is an increased incidence of pre-eclampsia and a tendency for postmaturity.
  • The pelvis is of the android type. The occipito-posterior position is common.
  • During labor, there is a tendency for deep transverse arrest or outlet dystocia, leading to difficult instrumental delivery or cesarean section.
  • There is a chance of lactation failure.

questions.text: A diabetic primigravida is suspected to have cephalopelvic disproportion. What should her obstetric conjugate be for a trial of labor to be conducted?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, a trial of labor or vaginal delivery can be allowed if the obstetric conjugate is 10cm or more. 

The obstetric conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis. Normally, it is 10 cm or more. 

The diagonal conjugate measures 12cm and the true conjugate measures 11cm.

Clinically, only the diagonal conjugate is assessed by measuring the distance between the base of the examiner's fingers and the fingertip touching the sacral promontory.  This determines the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory. The obstetric conjugate is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate. 

Note: Overt diabetes can cause fetal macrosomia during pregnancy. Thus, it may lead to cephalopelvic disproportion.

Given below is an image of the lateral plane in CT pelvimetry, showing the anteroposterior diameters of the pelvis. Line no. 4 is the obstetric conjugate and line no. 5 is the pelvic outlet.

questions.text: How many fontanelles are present in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Newborns have a total of 6 fontanelles. These are fibrous, membrane-covered gaps between cranial bones.

The fontanelles seen in newborns are:

  • Anterior fontanelle:
    • It is also called bregma. 
    • Diameter ranges from 0.6-3.6 cm, with a mean of 2.1 cm.
    • It completely closes by 24 months of age.
  • Posterior fontanelle:
    • It is also called lambda.
    • Diameter ranges from 0.5-0.7 cm.
    • It completely closes by 2 months of age.
  • 2 sphenoid fontanelles
  • 2 mastoid fontanelles

Note: A third fontanelle between the anterior and posterior fontanels is associated with hypothyroidism and Down's syndrome.

questions.text: The pediatrician notices a diffuse, reddish scalp swelling in a newborn born by vacuum extraction. Which of the following is not a characteristic of this condition?

choices.text: It does not disappear within 2-3 days.
It is a diffuse edematous swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp.

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of caput succedaneum which disappears within 2-3 days.

In vertex presentation, labor forces alter the shape of the fetal head. In prolonged labor, before complete cervical dilatation, the portion of the fetal scalp immediately over the cervical os becomes edematous. A swelling is formed is due to the stagnation of fluid in the layers of the scalp beneath the girdle of contact. This is known as caput succedaneum.

The swelling is diffuse, boggy, and not limited by the suture lines. It resolves spontaneously within 2-3 days after birth. It is a result of the static position of the head for a long period of time.

Chignon is a type of artificial caput succedaneum, which is a swelling produced on the fetal head because of the scalp getting sucked into the cup during vacuum extraction. 

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: At what period of gestation are the weights of the fetus and placenta equal?
questions.solution:
At 17 weeks, the weights of the fetus and placenta are equal.

In the first trimester, the placental growth is more rapid than that of the fetus. By approximately 17 weeks, the placental weight and fetal weight are almost equal. And by term, placental weight is approximately 1/6th of the fetal weight.

questions.text: Ultrasound of a 24-year-old primigravida at 20 weeks of gestation shows the presence of a single umbilical artery. No other gross fetal anomalies were detected.  Which of the following is true regarding this finding?

choices.text: It is an indicator of increased risk of malformations of the fetus
Equally common in newborns of diabetic and non-diabetic mothers

questions.solution:
A single umbilical artery is the most common aberration of vessel number in the umbilical cord. It indicates an increased risk of congenital malformations in the fetus.

A single umbilical artery is seen in the following conditions: 

  • Twin pregnancy
  • Gestational diabetes/Overt diabetes
  • Epilepsy
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Preeclampsia
  • Antepartum hemorrhage 

It is frequently associated with congenital malformations of the fetus (20–25%) such as:

  • Cardiovascular anomalies
  • Genitourinary anomalies
  • Trisomy 18

It increases the risks of adverse obstetric outcomes like:

  • Abortion
  • Fetal aneuploidy
  • Prematurity
  • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Perinatal mortality

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for amnioinfusion?
questions.solution:
Transvaginal amnioinfusion is not used to facilitate labor. It is used for the following:

  • Treatment of variable or prolonged decelerations
  • As prophylaxis for women with oligohydramnios due to prolonged ruptured membranes
  • To dilute or wash out thick meconium
  • To reduce fetal gasping which is the result of hypoxia occurring due to cord compression

questions.text: Given below is the hysterosalpingogram of a woman who presented with infertility. Identify the uterine anomaly seen.
questions.solution:
In a hysterosalpingogram, the uterine anomaly cannot be determined as the external contour of the uterus cannot be seen. 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity. However, it doesn't show the external contour, so it cannot distinguish between uterine anomalies such as didelphys, bicornuate, septate or arcuate uteruses.

Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV-US) is very accurate for the diagnosis and differentiation of uterine anomalies. It is the first and only mandatory step in the assessment of the uterine cavity in patients with a suspected uterine anomaly.

Pelvic MRI without contrast provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours. It should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TV-US is not possible.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: What is diagnostic criterion for considering puberty to be delayed in girls?

choices.text: Absence of menstruation by the age of 14 years
Absence of secondary sexual characters by the age of 14 years
Absence of menstruation by the age of 15 years
Absence of secondary sexual characters by the age of 12 years

questions.solution:
Puberty would be considered to be delayed in any girl who has not started menstruating by the age of 15 years.

Delayed puberty in girls can be declared on the basis of 2 grounds. These are:

  • No secondary sexual characters are present by 13 years of age.
  • Secondary sexual characters are present, but no menses have occurred by 15 years of age.

If any one of these is present, it's considered to be a case of delayed puberty.

Precocious puberty is considered if breast development or onset of puberty occurs in children less than 8 years of age.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has come to your clinic. On examination, thelarche is absent. She has a normal stature, and her karyotype is 46XX. Which investigation would you prefer to perform first?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of primary amenorrhea. The first line of investigation in primary amenorrhea should be hormonal assay (LH, FSH, estrogen).

Following this investigation, USG pelvis and MRI pelvis can be performed to enable the anatomical assessment.

LH and FSH levels help to assess whether it is a hypogonadotropic or hypergonadotropic condition. The hormone replacement therapy is planned based on LH and FSH levels.

The various types of hypogonadism are as follows:

Type of Hypogonadism LH/FSH Estrogen Primary defect
Hypergonadotropic High Low Ovary
Hypogonadotropic Low Low Hypothalamus/Pituitary
Eugonadotropic Normal Normal Varied

Note: In a patient with primary amenorrhea with absent sexual characteristics, the first line of investigation is hormonal assay (LH and FSH levels).

questions.text: Which of the following is an aerobic bacterial flora of the lower reproductive tract?
questions.solution:
Proteus is an aerobic bacterial flora of the lower reproductive tract.

Lower reproductive tract bacterial flora includes:

Aerobes Anaerobes

Gram-positive cocci

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • Staphylococcus species
  • Group B Streptococcus
  • Enterococcus faecalis

Gram-positive cocci

  • Peptostreptococcus species

Gram-positive bacilli

  • Lactobacillus species
  • Diphtheroids

Gram-positive bacilli

  • Lactobacillus species
  • Propionibacterium species
  • Eubacterium species
  • Bifidobacterium species
  • Actinomyces israelii
  • Clostridium species

Gram-negative

  • Escherichia coli
  • Klebsiella species
  • Proteus species
  • Enterobacter species
  • Acinetobacter species
  • Citrobacter species
  • Pseudomonas species

Gram-negative

  • Prevotella species
  • Bacteroides species
  • Bacteroides fragilis group
  • Fusobacterium species
  • Veillonella species
 

Yeast

  • Candida albicans

questions.text: A 30-year old woman presents to your OPD with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge for the past 2 weeks. On examination, the discharge is adherent to the vaginal mucosa and has a fishy odour. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV) caused by Gardnerella. 

Patients with BV have profuse and yellowish vaginal discharge with a fishy odour. It is adherent to the vaginal mucosa. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are absent. On microscopy, clue cells are visible.

Option A: In trichomonas vaginitis, the vaginal discharge is frothy, greenish-yellow and has an offensive smell. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are generally present. 

Option B: In candidal vaginitis, the discharge is thick and curdy white.

Option D: In chlamydial infection, the vaginal discharge is generally scanty.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause genitourinary fistulas?
questions.solution:
Hysteroscopy is not an etiology for genitourinary fistulae. It can occur following hysterectomy. 

Most genitourinary fistulas are acquired. Its causes are enumerated below:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor - major cause in developing countries
  • Difficult instrumental or manipulative deliveries
  • Injury to bladder or ureter during hysterectomy - major cause in developed contries
  • Congenital (rare)
  • Other causes include:
    • Radiation
    • Malignancy
    • Trauma 
    • Infections - PID, tuberculosis etc.

questions.text: Intravenous pyelography in a patient suspected to have a genitourinary fistula revealed a ureteric fistula. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is mostly caused by gynecological surgeries
Continuous dribbling of urine occurs, but the patient can also micturate
In 3-swab test, the swab is stained blue
Hydronephrosis is present on the affected side

questions.solution:
Swabs stained with methylene blue are obtained in a bladder fistula and not in a ureteric fistula.

Ureteric fistulas can present with the following features:

  • Constant urinary dribbling
  • Flank pain or loin tenderness
  • Renal angle tenderness
  • Fever
  • Hematuria 
  • Oliguria

Ureteric fistulas are most commonly caused by iatrogenic trauma during pelvic surgeries, especially gynecological surgeries. An excretory urogram (intravenous pyelography) or a CT urogram are the investigations of choice. Hydronephrosis may be present on the affected side.

It is managed by performing a ureteroneocystostomy and percutaneous nephrostomy.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with a mass per vaginum and incontinence. She complains that she has to push the mass inwards to be able to urinate normally. What is the type of incontinence seen here?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a cystocele in a case of genital prolapse. Stress incontinence is seen in these cases.

In stress incontinence, involuntary leakage of urine occurs when there is increased intraabdominal pressure, such as during laughing, sneezing, or coughing. There is no normal urge to pass urine.

Option A: Urge incontinence is the involuntary voiding of urine when there is an imminent urge to urinate.

Option C: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge incontinence. 

Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs due to defects anywhere in the pathway of the micturition reflex, e.g., spinal cord trauma, diabetes etc. It presents with with urgency or urge incontinence.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primiparous woman with Grade 2 genuine stress incontinence did not respond to conservative management. Which of the following surgeries will not be beneficial for her condition?
questions.solution:
Latzko procedure is not beneficial for a patient with genuine stress incontinence as it is done for vesicovaginal fistula.

The various surgeries done for genuine stress incontinence (GSI) are as follows:

  • Vaginal approach
    • Kelly repair
    • Pacey repair
  • Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It is not done anymore as it causes osteitis of the pubis.
  • Burch colposuspension
  • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation
  • Slings
    • Tension-free vaginal taping
    • Transobturator taping
  • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck
  • Periurethral collagen injection

questions.text: A menopausal woman presents with complaints of hot flushes. Which of the following neurotransmitters are responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Norepinephrine and serotonin are responsible for hot flushes in menopausal women.

A fall in the level of estrogen causes a reduction in hypothalamic endorphins. This causes a release of more norepinephrine and serotonin, which lower the set point in the thermoregulatory nucleus. As a result, the heat-loss mechanism is triggered by even subtle changes in core body temperature.

Risk factors for hot flushes:

  • Low estradiol levels
  • High BMI
  • Sedentary lifestyle
  • Surgical menopause has increased risk
  • Low socioeconomic status
  • History of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD)
  • Depression.

questions.text: Reduction in breast size in post-menopausal women is due to the withdrawal of ______.
questions.solution:
The reduction in breast size in postmenopausal women is due to the withdrawal of estrogen and progesterone. 

Estrogen exerts proliferative effects on the ductal component, while progesterone exerts a proliferative effect on the glandular component.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about hormone replacement therapy and breast cancer?

choices.text: Cancer risk is not increased up to 3 years of combined HRT
Cancer risk is not increased up to 5 years of estrogen-only replacement therapy
HRT impedes screening for breast cancer with mammography
HRT may cause high grade breast cancer with poor prognosis

questions.solution:
Breast cancer developing subsequent to HRT is of low grade and has a good prognosis.

The risk of breast cancer is not increased up to 3 years of HRT and 5 years of estrogen-only replacement therapy. Lower risk is seen with the use of dydrogesterone in HRT.

HRT can cause recurrence of breast cancer and is, therefore, contraindicated in a woman who has been treated for breast cancer.

HRT increases the density of breast tissue and subsequently impedes the screening for breast cancer with mammography.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presenting with acute abdominal pain had previously been diagnosed with uterine fibroids. Which of the following complications is most unlikely to have occurred here?
questions.solution:
Hyaline degeneration of fibroids is unlikely here as it is usually painless and presents as an abdominal mass causing distension and heaviness.

Acute pain in fibroids is seen in the case of: 

  • Fibroid torsion
  • Hemorrhage into the fibroid
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change - seen in postmenopausal women.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with leiomyoma was prescribed an intranasal spray to manage her disease. Which of the following drugs is it unlikely to contain?
questions.solution:
The nasal spray is unlikely to contain histrelin, as it is only available as a subcutaneous implant. 

GnRH analogues are used to treat leiomyomas. Intranasal preparations are available for leuprolide, nafarelin, and buserelin. However, leuprolide has maximal action as an intramuscular injection. 

GnRH analogue therapy in fibroids is given as follows:

  • Leuprolide acetate (Lupron) - given intramuscularly. It is also available as an intranasal spray, but isn't commonly used. 
  • Goserelin (Zoladex) - subcutaneous depot implant
  • Triptorelin (Trelstar) IM injection
  • Nafarelin and buserelin - given as intranasal sprays bd 
  • Histrelin - available as subcutaneous implants.

questions.text: Which of the following is an uncommon etiology for prolapse?
questions.solution:
Congenital prolapse is an uncommon cause of prolapse. 

The most important etiological factors that lead to prolapse are the atonicity of the uterus and asthenia, which occurs due to aging and follows menopause.

The other factors which lead to prolapse are as follows:

  • Pregnancy
  • Vaginal childbirth
  • Menopause
    • Aging
    • Hypoestrogenism
  • Peripheral nerve injury to the pudendal nerve
  • Premature bearing down before full dilatation of the cervix
  • Chronically increased intra-abdominal pressure
    • Chronic bronchitis
    • Constipation
    • Obesity
  • Spina bifida occulta
  • Congenital weakness of pelvic floor muscles
  • Abdominoperineal excision of rectum 
  • Surgeries such as Stamey and Pereyra operation for stress incontinence

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of a mass descending PV. On examination, you note that the external os lies at the level of the introitus. What is the degree of uterine prolapse?
questions.solution: The given case scenario is suggestive of 2nd degree prolapse.

questions.text: A sexually active woman presented to a rural PHC with itching over the vulval region for a year. On examination, multiple lesions were noted over the vulva. Biopsy revealed cellular abnormality without stromal invasion involving the entire thickness of the vulva. What is the likely degree of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and biopsy finding of cellular abnormality involving the entire thickness of the vulva is suggestive of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) 3.

Degrees of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN): 

Degree Cellular abnormality  Other features
VIN 1 Limited to the basal layer Lower 1/3rd of the vulval epithelium is involved
VIN 2

Basal & intermediate layer

Lower 2/3rd of vulval epithelium  is involved

Commonly associated with HPV
VIN 3

Entire thickness of the vulval epithelium is involved

No vascular/ lymphatic invasion

 2 types:

  • Young patients - HPV +ve, multiple lesions, 90% regress
  • Elderly patients - HPV –ve, single lesion, associated with lichen sclerosis, often progresses to invasive cancer

questions.text: In patients with vulval cancer, what is the least common route through which the malignancy spreads?
questions.solution:
Vascular route of spread is rare in vulval cancer. Lymphatic is the most common route of spread in vulval cancer.

Lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor. The sentinel lymph node biopsy is helpful for evaluating the spread of vulval cancer. Lymph nodes involved are, superficial inguinal nodes (sentinel node) > deep inguinal nodes > femoral group of nodes.

questions.text:
Which of the following constitute corpus cancer syndrome?
  1. Obesity
  2. Hypertension
  3. Stroke
  4. Diabetes mellitus 
  5. Endometrial carcinoma
  6. Dysgerminoma
questions.solution:
Corpus cancer syndrome constitutes of:

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Hypertension
  • Cancer of the body of the uterus.

Etiology of endometrial carcinoma: (Mnemonic: Family Has OLD AUNTI)

  • Family history
  • Hypertension
  • Obesity
  • Late menopause/Early menarche
  • Diabetes
  • Atypical endometrial hyperplasia
  • Unopposed estrogen/increased estrogen → Hormone replacement therapy, fibroid, PCOD
  • Nulliparous
  • Tamoxifen therapy (Raloxifene has no genito-urinary action)
  • Infertility/irregular menses.

Protective factors against endometrial carcinoma include the use of OCPs, smoking, and multiparity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old nulliparous woman presents to you with primary infertility. On examination, stage 2 uterine prolapse is present. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse, who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function

Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy - cervical supports are fixed to the abdominal wall
  • Shirodkar’s sling operation - cervix is fixed to the lumbosacral fascia using Mersilene tape
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation - isthmus of the cervix is fixed to the anterior superior iliac spines. It is not done anymore due to the risk of periosteitis. 
  • Virkud's sling operation - the tape is fixed from the isthmus and attached to the rectus compartment 
  • Joshi's sling operation - the uterus is suspended from the pectineal ligaments.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Nulliparous or congenital prolapse

  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)

  • Le Fort's repair

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: When does the sexual differentiation of the fetus occur?
questions.solution:
Sexual differentiation of the fetus occurs only after the 7th week of development. 

The chromosomal and genetic sex of an embryo is determined at fertilization by the kind of sperm that fertilizes the ovum (X or Y). However, male and female morphological characteristics begin developing after the 7th week. At the end of the 6th week of development, it is impossible to distinguish between the two sexes.

Related Pearl: Sexual Differentiation

questions.text: Which is the most common type of ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
Epithelial tumors are the most common type of ovarian tumors.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: A patient with genital TB has been put on treatment with ATT. Which of her medications is bacteriostatic?
questions.solution:
Ethambutol is a bacteriostatic drug as it only prevents the growth of mycobacteria.

All the other drugs mentioned, kill the mycobacteria and so they are bactericidal. These four drugs are all included in anti-tubercular treatment (ATT) provided under NTEP.

Anti-tubercular treatment for extra-pulmonary tuberculosis forms the crux of the treatment of genital TB. However, IVF needs to be done if there is a tubal blockage leading to infertility in these patients. 

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

SLI: Second Line Injectable

questions.text:
The laparoscopy report of a woman with pelvic inflammatory disease states she has Gainesville stage III PID. Which of the following presentations could have been seen in her?
  1. Acute salpingitis with peritonitis.
  2. Acute salpingitis with no adhesions.
  3. Acute salpingitis with tubo-ovarian complex
  4. Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess
  5. Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion
questions.solution:
Gainesville stage III includes two forms of PID - acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex.

Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage as follows:

Stage

Condition 

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - no adhesions 

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis - purulent discharge  

Stage III

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess 

Stage V

Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: A post-coital test was done in a couple who presented with an inability to conceive despite staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. Which of the following conditions cannot be detected by this test?
questions.solution:
The post-coital test can not detect a fallopian tube block. It can evaluate the following conditions:

  • Sperm count
  • Sperm morphology
  • Ferning during the estrogenic effect
  • Ovulation
  • The ability of the cervical mucous to allow sperm penetration
  • Detection of anti-sperm antibodies in the cervical mucous

In the post-coital test, the couple is advised to have intercourse early in the morning close to the ovulation phase. The woman is asked to visit the clinic within 2 hours of having intercourse. The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide. Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control.

On microscopy, 10–50 motile sperms are normally seen per high-power field. The cervical mucus is also examined for its quantity and viscosity. The post-coital test is useless in the presence of cervical infection.

An immunological factor causing infertility is encountered in around 5% of infertile couples.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man underwent semen analysis as a part of an infertility workup. The results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Sperm concentration - 16 million/ml
  • pH - 7.5
  • Volume - 2 mL
  • Agglutination is absent
  • Morphology - 60% normal and 60% motile sperms
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is normospermia.

Different types of disorders of sperms are as follows:

  • Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen.
  • Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL.
  • Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL.
  • Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology.
  • Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility.
  • Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms.

Note: Morphology > motility is the most important marker in sperm analysis.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: The following instrument is used to augment labour in a 28-year-old primigravida via low rupture of membranes. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is Kocher's artery forceps and is identified by the presence of a single tooth at the tip.

Kocher's artery forceps are used to achieve hemostasis by holding bleeding vessels. They are also used in low rupture of membranes to augment labour or for the surgical induction of labour. 

The difference between artery forceps and needle holders is in the edge and smoothness of corrugations. Artery forceps have smooth edges and single lined corrugations whereas, needle holders have rough edges and crossed lines forming square to diamond shaped corrugations.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is most commonly used for the treatment of CIN?

choices.text: Large loop excision of transformation zone

questions.solution:
Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ) is the most commonly used treatment option for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). It is also known as loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP).

It is applicable for the treatment of CIN anywhere in the lower genital tract. This uses electric current through a monopolar wire electrode to either cut or coagulate cervical lesions. Like other excisional procedures, it is done in the immediate post menstrual phase.

The procedure involves minimal patient discomfort, cost, and complications. Since it can be performed using local anesthesia, it has become the primary outpatient treatment modality for high-grade cervical lesions.

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: The CT of a patient with cervical carcinoma revealed a lesion of 6 cm, extending to the upper part of the vagina and parametrium. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The stage of cervical carcinoma is II B as it involves the upper part of the vagina and parametrium.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is performed using the instrument given in the image?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a menstrual regulation syringe fitted with a Karman's cannula. Menstrual regulation involves aspiration of the contents of the endometrial cavity within 14 days of a missed period in a woman with previously normal cycles.

Procedure of menstrual regulation:

  • The cervix is gently dilated using 4-5 mm-sized dilators.
  • A 5-6 mm Karman's cannula is then inserted and attached to a 50 mL syringe for suction.
  • The cannula is rotated and pushed in and out with gentle strokes.

Contraindications of menstrual regulation:

  • Advanced pregnancy
  • Local pelvic inflammation

Manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) is done with an MVA syringe fitted with the Karman's cannula up to 12 weeks of gestation.

 

Suction and evacuation is done using a Karman's cannula attached to an automated suction apparatus.

questions.text: A woman with 6 weeks of amenorrhea had a positive urine pregnancy test. The following finding was seen on transabdominal USG. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given USG image shows an empty gestational sac which is seen in missed abortion before 12 weeks. At this gestational age,  the entire ovum is covered by the chorionic villi giving rise to the empty gestational sac.

If this condition occurs beyond 12 weeks of gestation, a dead fetus is seen on USG. This is not preceded by any warning signs and the fetus is not expelled outside spontaneously.

Related Pearl: Clinical classification of Spontaneous Abortion

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient came for medical termination of pregnancy. From whom will you obtain consent for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Only the patient's consent is required for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) and her male partner's consent is not required.

Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 yrs or if the patient is mentally ill.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.
