questions.text: A patient with cervical insufficiency is posted for McDonald's procedure.  Which of the following is not a contraindication for this surgery?
questions.solution:
McDonald's procedure is a type of cervical cerclage. It can be done up to 24 weeks of gestation.

Contraindications to cervical cerclage are: 

  • Absolute
    • >24 weeks of gestation 
    • Active labour
    • Active vaginal bleeding
    • Abruptio placenta
    • Premature rupture of membranes
    • Chorioamnionitis
    • Severe uterine irritability
    • Fetal death or defect
  • Relative
    • Prolapsed membranes
    • Vaginal spotting

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman presented with placental abruption and was delivered by normal vaginal delivery. The next day, she develops petechiae, cold extremities, and her BP drops to 90/60 mmHg. Her blood reports show increased FDP, D-dimer, and decreased platelets. Which of the following is not used in the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Epsilon-aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid are not used in the treatment of DIC.

Evaluation and management of DIC:

  • Vigorous restoration and maintenance of circulation to treat hypotension
    • Crystalloids and colloids to treat hypotension
    • Whole blood and packed cells
    • Fresh frozen plasma - contains fibrinogen, antithrombin III, factors V, XI, XII
    • Cryoprecipitate - contains fibrinogen, factor VIII, von Willebrand’s factor, factor XIII
    • Platelet replacement if low
  • Identification of the cause:
    • Abruptio placenta
    • PPH
    • HELLP syndrome
    • Amniotic fluid embolism
    • Sepsis
    • Acute fatty liver
  • Assess the fetal condition and plan for termination of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the labour room with lower abdominal pain. Her vitals are BP - 90/60 mmHg and PR - 120 bpm. Fetal distress was noted and she was taken up for a caesarean section. The uterus appears as shown below.  Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in revealed abruptio placenta
It is an indication for hysterectomy
It is a case of uteroplacental apoplexy

questions.solution:
The given image shows a couvelaire uterus or uteroplacental apoplexy which is seen in severe forms of concealed abruptio placenta. 

There is massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serosa. Thus, the uterus has a port wine colour, which can be patchy or diffuse. They can also extend to the broad ligament, ovaries and peritoneal cavity.

It is usually observed during caesarean section. It is not an indication of hysterectomy.

questions.text: The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism includes all except _____.
questions.solution:
The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism does not include metabolic acidosis.

Classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism:

  • Hypotension
  • Hypoxia
  • DIC

Conditions predisposing to the development of amniotic fluid embolism:

  1. Rapid labour
  2. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid
  3. Tears in uterine and other large pelvic veins
  4. Older maternal age
  5. Post-term pregnancy
  6. Labour induction or augmentation
  7. Eclampsia
  8. Cesarean/forceps/vacuum delivery
  9. Placental abruption/placenta previa
  10. Polyhydramnios.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations can be used in the antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa in a patient with no history of bleeding PV?
questions.solution:
The antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa can be done by colour doppler.

Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture.

Fetal mortality is high due to fetal exsanguination.

Investigations of vasa previa:

  • Colour flow Doppler (TVS)
  • Singer's alkali denaturation test - to detect nucleated red blood cells
  • Apt test - to detect fetal haemoglobin

Management of vasa previa:

  • No bleeding
    • 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids
    • 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance
    • ≥37 weeks - elective caesarean section
  • Bleeding present
    • Emergency caesarean section done by category I

Options A and B: Colour Doppler is superior to MRI and TAS in the antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa.

Option D: Singer's alkali denaturation test to detect fetal RBCs can be used in intrapartum diagnosis of vasa previa (as there might be bleeding).

questions.text: A G2P1 woman was diagnosed with placental accreta. Which of the following findings will be seen on the USG of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ultrasound imaging in a patient with placenta accreta shows large placental lacunae.

Ultrasound findings in placenta accreta:

  • Loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between uterus and placenta
  • Placental vascular lacunae
  • Placental bulging into the posterior bladder wall

The following image shows the placenta accreta with a large placental lacuna without any myometrial invasion.

 

Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, then the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.

Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells. This decidual deficiency then prevents normal placental separation after delivery.

It is of three types:

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

 

Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Ring of fire appearance is seen on color doppler in ectopic pregnancy.

Option C: Thick myometrium with retroplacental clots is seen in TAS in abruptio placenta.

Option D: Snowstorm appearance is seen in TAS in molar pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Per speculum examination findings in a pregnant woman with vaginal bleeding showed placenta protruding through the cervical os. What is the type of placenta previa in this case?
questions.solution:
Placenta protruding through the internal os on per speculum examination indicates complete placenta previa or type IV placenta previa.

Older (Browne's) classification of placenta previa:

Type

Position

Definition

Type I

Lateral 

The placenta dips into the lower segment but does not reach up to the os

Type II

Marginal

The placental edge reaches the os

Type III

Incomplete or partial central

The placenta partially covers the internal os 

Type IV

Complete or central

The placenta completely covers the internal os

Cervical digital examination must only be done in suspected cases of placenta previa in an operation theater with provisions for cesarean section kept ready.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
The first-line agents used in the management of Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC) infections are trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole), meropenem, minocycline, and ceftazidime (3rd generation cephalosporin).

Other options:

Option A: Burkholderia species are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides and polymyxins.

Option C: Tigecycline is less effective in the case of Burkholderia infections.

Option D: Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporins have the same mechanism of action and compete for the same binding site. Hence, it is not a rational drug combination. 

BCC is a group of bacteria known for causing severe respiratory distress and septicemia, particularly in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). BCC organisms are also found in ICU patients and individuals with chronic granulomatous disease, leading to lung disease. BCC colonization in CF patients prior to lung transplantation increases the risk of death during the early transplant period.

Related Pearl: List of intrinsic drug resistance in bacteria

 

Organism Intrinsic Drug Resistance

Acinetobacter baumanii

Ampicillin,Amoxicillin,Ertapenem,Trimethoprim,Chloramphenicol
Pseudomonas aeruginosa Ampicillin,Amoxicillin-Clavulanate,Ceftriaxone,Ertapenem,Tetracyclines/Tigecyclines, Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole,Chloramphenicol
Bacteroides fragilis Aminoglycosides,Ampicillin
Gram positive bacteria Aztreonam
Staphylococcus saprophyticus  Novobiocin
Enterococcus fecalis/fecium Cephalosporins,Aminoglycosides,Clindamycin,Polymyxin B
Clostridium species  Aminoglycosides
Gram negative bacteria Vancomycin
Klebsiella pneumoniae Ampicillin
Enterobacter Ampicillin
Aerobic bacteria Metronidazole
Lactobacillus & Leuconostoc Vancomycin
Burkholderia Polymyxins and aminoglycosides

questions.text: Transvaginal ultrasound findings in a multiparous woman revealed a low lying placenta. What does this mean?

choices.text: Placental edge within 2 cm from the internal os
Placental edge within 3 cm from the internal os
Placental edge within 4 cm from the internal os

questions.solution:
In low lying placenta, the edge of the placenta lies within 2 cm from the internal os but does not cover the internal os.

Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted over the lower uterine segment (partially or completely).

ACOG classification of placenta previa:

  • True placenta previa - placenta covers the internal os partially or completely
  • Low lying placenta - placenta does not cover the internal os but the edge is within 2 cm of the internal os

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation?
questions.solution:
Supine vena cava syndrome is the complication of the given representation. The image shows compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus which can sometimes lead to supine hypotension.

During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the great vessels against the hard spine, when the patient is in the supine position. Of the two vessels, the vena cava is compressed, but the aorta, owing to its structure is relatively resistant.

Normally, the vena cava compression results in opening up collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygous veins but in some cases, when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed resulting in hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope and is called supine vena cava syndrome.

The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to the lateral position.

questions.text: A G2P1 patient at 25 weeks of gestation is brought to the emergency with right upper quadrant pain and one episode of seizure. CBC reveals a Hb of 7.6gm/dl and a platelet count of 70,000/microL. What is the definitive management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and HELLP syndrome. The definitive management is the termination of pregnancy.

In cases of pre-eclampsia, indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age, are as follows:

  • Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor)
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Persistent symptoms of severe pre-eclampsia or severe hypertension
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy
  • Abruption of placenta
  • Fetal compromise

In mild pre-eclampsia, steroids are given and the patient is delivered at 37 weeks.

In severe pre-eclampsia:

  • If pregnancy is >34 weeks - MgSO4 is given for prophylaxis of eclampsia and the pregnancy is terminated.
  • If pregnancy is at 27-34 weeks - in the absence of contraindications, expectant management is followed and the baby is delivered at 34 weeks, as shown below in the flowchart.

questions.text: The antihypertensives under trial for pre-eclampsia treatment include all except:
questions.solution:
Bosentan is not an antihypertensive under trial for pre-eclampsia treatment. It is a drug used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Experimental antihypertensive drugs for pre-eclampsia treatment include:

  • Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP)
  • Antidigoxin antibody fab (DIF) - directed against endogenous digitalis-like factors, also called cardiotonic steroid.

questions.text: A patient, diagnosed with preeclampsia was brought to the emergency room with three episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, urinary incontinence, and altered sensorium for 3 hours. After stabilization, an MRI revealed the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Anterior circulation is most commonly involved
This lesions may be seen in most pre-eclampsia patients

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and radiological image are suggestive of posterior reversible leukoencephalopathy syndrome (PRES). This condition is usually reversible.

Endothelial dysfunction and cerebral autoregulation failure are implicated as etiologies of PRES. PRES lesions are almost universal in women with eclampsia but less frequent in pre-eclampsia.

PRES is characterized by the following:

  • Severe headaches
  • Altered sensorium
  • Seizures
  • Visual disturbances. 

Radiological findings in PRES:

  • Hyperintense T2 lesions in the subcortical and cortical regions of the parietal and occipital lobes.
  • The basal ganglia, brainstem, and cerebellum are commonly involved.
  • Posterior circulation is commonly involved, and anterior circulation involvement is seen in severe cases.

Neurological manifestations of preeclampsia include:

  • Headaches 
  • Convulsions
  • Cerebral edema
  • Blindness 
  • Cerebral hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which finding is most likely to be seen in a patient with pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
Decreased GFR is seen in pre-eclampsia.

During normal pregnancy, renal blood flow and GFR are increased. However, in pre-eclampsia, renal blood flow and GFR decrease due to increased renal afferent arteriolar resistance. The hallmark renal lesion is glomerular endotheliosis. Diminished filtration causes serum creatinine levels and plasma uric acid concentration levels to rise. The elevation is also due to enhanced tubular reabsorption.

The most common system involved in pre-eclampsia is the renal system.

Several studies have demonstrated that pre-eclampsia is associated with low urinary calcium. This is often used as a predictive test.

questions.text: In gestational diabetes, which of the following is an independent and substantial risk factor for macrosomia?
questions.solution:
BMI (body mass index) is an independent and substantial risk factor for macrosomia in both diabetic and non-diabetic mothers.

BMI levels are associated with increased birth weight, regardless of glucose levels. Gestational diabetes prevalence increases by approximately 1 percent for every 1 kg/m2 increase in BMI.

BMI cutoffs for pregnancy:

Underweight - < 18 kg/m2 

Normal - 18.5 to 24.9 kg/m2 

Overweight - 25 to 29.9 kg/m2 

Obese - >30 kg/m2 

Weight distribution also seems to play a role because the risk of gestational diabetes is increased with truncal obesity. HbA1c levels are associated with fetal malformations in pre-gestational diabetes.

questions.text: A primigravida on screening was found to have a fasting blood glucose of more than 100 mg/dl. Which of the following medications will you not prescribe to her?
questions.solution:
Tolbutamide is not used for the treatment of gestational diabetes. 

First-generation sulfonylureas such as tolbutamide and chlorpropamide can cause teratogenicity, neonatal hypoglycemia, and fetal hyperinsulinemia.

First-line glycemic control agents in pregnancy:

  • Insulin
  • Glyburide 
  • Metformin

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the highest risk of maternal mortality during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Eisenmenger syndrome is the heart disease with the worst prognosis, having a maternal mortality rate of 50%.

The most common cause of death in Eisenmenger’s syndrome is right ventricular failure with cardiogenic shock. If antenatal diagnosis of Eisenmenger syndrome is made in the first trimester, termination of pregnancy is advised. Eisenmenger syndrome has the highest risk of maternal mortality. However, since mitral stenosis is the most common cardiac condition in pregnancy, it is the most common cause of maternal mortality overall. 

Mitral regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse and pulmonary stenosis are well tolerated during pregnancy. Severe aortic stenosis can be life-threatening. However, women with mild to moderate aortic valve stenosis may have a relatively low-risk pregnancy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady came to the antenatal OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. Her UPT is positive.  She is a known case of mitral stenosis for 5 years.  Which is the best time to do surgery for mitral stenosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The best time of surgery for mitral stenosis in pregnancy is between 14–18 weeks.

Balloon valvuloplasty is the procedure of choice for mitral stenosis in pregnancy. Any cardiac surgery in pregnancy should usually be postponed until after delivery, but if required, it can be performed safely in the 2nd trimester.

questions.text: General anesthesia is the preferable mode of analgesia in pregnant women with ______
questions.solution:
In pregnant ladies with intracardiac shunts, general anesthesia is the preferable mode of analgesia.

The major problem with epidural/spinal analgesia is maternal hypotension. This is especially dangerous in women with intracardiac shunts in whom flow may be reversed (blood passes from right to left and bypasses the lungs). So in case of a shunt lesion, only general anesthesia should be given.

Note: Aortic stenosis will also be affected by the hypotension caused by epidural/spinal analgesia. However, in aortic stenosis, slow epidural anesthesia is adequate and doesn't compromise ventricular preload. Only a few severe cases of aortic stenosis warrant GA. Hence, in the context of this MCQ, 'intracardiac shunts' would be the most appropriate answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an absolute indication for therapeutic termination of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Prosthetic valve replacement is not an indication for therapeutic termination as it comes under the WHO category risk 3. Only conditions included under WHO category risk 4 are considered as indications for termination of pregnancy.

WHO class 4 comprises of diseases with very high risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity, such as:

  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension
  • Severe systemic ventricular dysfunction (NYHA III-IV or LVEF 30-40%)
  • Previous peripartum cardiomyopathy with any residual impairment of left ventricular function
  • Severe left heart obstruction
  • Marfan syndrome with aorta dilated >40 mm

Termination of pregnancy is also advised in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady with rheumatic mitral stenosis becomes pregnant. At what point during her pregnancy would you be least concerned about her developing cardiac failure?
questions.solution:
Cardiac failure in pregnancy is least likely to occur during 24 weeks, considering the given options.

The order of risk of cardiac failure in pregnancy is immediate postpartum > 2nd stage of labor > 30 weeks > 22 weeks.

Maternal cardiac risk predictors: [Mnemonic: NOPE]

  N-NYHA class >2

  O-Obstructive lesions of left heart (Mitral valve area <2 cm2  or aortic valve area <1.5 cm2, peak LV outflow tract gradient >30 mmHg)

  P-Prior cardiac events before pregnancy

  E-Ejection fraction <40%

Scoring systems used to calculate risk are Cardiac Disease in Pregnancy (CARPREG) and ZAHARA scores.

questions.text: In modified Liley's (Queenan) chart, which zone represents a severely affected fetus?
questions.solution:
A severely affected fetus is represented by zone 3.

Liley developed a chart of changing amniotic fluid bilirubin levels (delta OD450) and weeks of gestation. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable as a change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm (ΔOD450).

However, middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PCV) is non-invasive and more accurate than optical density at 450 nm, hence Liley’s chart is no longer used in practice.

Liley’s chart has three zones as shown below, delineating the severity of rhesus disease.

  • Liley’s zone I (low zone) - mild disease. 
  • Liley’s zone II (mid zone) - fetal anemia.
  • Liley’s zone III (high zone) - severely affected fetus and fetal death is imminent.

questions.text: An Rh-negative G2P1 mother delivered her Rh-positive baby by cesarean section. Kleihaeur Betke test, as shown in the image, was done. Which of the following statements is true regarding the test?

choices.text: Fetal erythrocytes are the ghost cells
The reagent used is citric acid

questions.solution:
The reagent used for the Kleihauer-Betke test is citric acid.

Kleihauer-Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test used to detect fetomaternal hemorrhage i.e., the approximate volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation. It is also known as the acid elution test.

The principle behind it is that fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A.

After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as “ghosts.” Fetal cells are counted and expressed as a percentage of adult cells.

Flow cytometry is the best test for the quantification of fetomaternal hemorrhage. It is more sensitive and accurate as compared to the Kleihauer-Betke test. 

Flow cytometry can analyze a larger number of cells and is not influenced by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin and fetal levels of maternal hemoglobin. It utilizes monoclonal antibodies to HbF or to the D antigen followed by quantification by fluorescence.

questions.text: An Rh-negative patient who did not have access to antenatal care delivered a stillborn fetus as shown in the image. Which of the following is not associated with the fetal condition?
questions.solution:
The pale, oedematous fetus in the image is suggestive of fetal hydrops. Fetal hydrops is associated with polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios. 

It often occurs as an effect of iso-immunization in an Rh-negative pregnancy. Other complications that may occur are fetal anemia and hyperbilirubinemia. 

Fetal anemia occurs in the initial stage of iso-immunization. It is associated with polyhydramnios and increased placental thickening (hyper-placentosis). An increase in the right atrium size of the fetus is seen.

Fetal hydrops is usually accompanied by severe anemia. It results in stillbirth or fetal demise soon after birth. It is also associated with:

  • Congestive cardiac failure 
  • Ascites 
  • Pleural effusion 
  • Pericardial effusion 
  • Hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: What is the most common complication seen in face to pubis delivery?
questions.solution:
The most common complication seen in face to pubis delivery is complete perineal tears.

In face to pubis delivery, the occiput is posterior, and therefore, the largest biparietal diameter (9.4 cm) distends the perineum rather than the smaller bitemporal diameter (8 cm). A liberal episiotomy helps to avoid perineal tears.

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: A neonate is noted to have Klumpke's paralysis of the left arm following delivery. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the associated fetal presentation?
questions.solution:
Klumpke's paralysis is associated with difficult breech delivery, which is due to hyperabduction of the arm during traction and delivery of the fetus. Preeclampsia is not a risk factor for breech presentation.

Risk factors for breech presentation:  

  • Early gestational age
  • Abnormal amnionic fluid volume
  • Multifetal gestation
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Anencephaly
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Placenta previa
  • Fundal placental implantation
  • High parity with uterine relaxation
  • Prior breech delivery
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Smoking.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Vagos method used?
questions.solution:
Vagos method is used in cord prolapse.

Vagos method is also known as the bladder filling method. Here, the bladder is distended with saline to push the presenting part higher up, thereby preventing compression in case of cord prolapse. The bladder is filled with 400–750 mL of normal saline with a Foley’s catheter. Then, the balloon is inflated and the catheter is clamped.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with the following fetal presentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Breech type Description Presenting part
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia
Footling Both thighs and legs are partially extended Foot 
Knee  Thighs extended, Knee flexed Knee
Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed. Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: A G2P1 obese woman was diagnosed with arrest of descent during labour. Identify the following manoeuvre performed for this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. 

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen).
  • The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby. 
  • Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position.

Rubin's manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position. 
  • Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder.

Wood corkscrew manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position.
  • Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding 11 years after she had attained menopause. An endometrial biopsy reveals adenocarcinoma. What is the gold standard method for staging her condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts endometrial carcinoma and the gold standard method for staging this condition is surgery.

According to FIGO/TNM classification system, a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and pelvic and para-aortic lymph node dissection is the standard staging procedure for endometrial cancer. 

Option A: Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) appears to be the best radiographic modality for detecting myometrial invasion or cervical involvement.

Option C: Hysteroscopy visualizes the entire uterine lining and a biopsy is taken from suspicious areas. This is not 100% predictive, as an early lesion can be missed. Recently, the concern has been raised regarding the spilling of cancer cells into the peritoneal cavity during hysteroscopy.

Option D: PET–CT reveals metabolic activity in the tissue and is highly sensitive and specific for detecting positive pelvic and/or para-aortic lymphadenopathy as well as distant metastases in selected high-risk patients with endometrial cancer.
